anchor.surface_text: The main point for consideration - thus is whether the particular provision introduced in sub-section g of section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act in 1929 is but a statutory recognition of a principle of justice, equity and good conscience, or whether it is merely a procedural and technical rule introduced in the section by the legislature and is not based on any well established principles of equity.

arguments.claim: English law does not require notice for forfeiture on non-payment of rent; institution of ejectment suit manifests election

anchor.surface_text: In England it is not necessary in case of non-payment of rent for a landlord to give notice before a forfeiture results. It cannot, therefore, be said that what has been enacted in sub-section g of section 111 is a matter which even today in English law is considered as a matter of justice, equity and good conscience. arguments.claim: For pre-TPA leases, forfeiture complete on breach; suit for ejectment manifests lessor's election, no prior notice or act needed

anchor.surface_text: The bringing by a landlord of a suit for ejectment is simply a mode of manifesting his election. The principle of these cases rests upon the ground that the forfeiture is complete when the breach of the condition or the denial of title occurs. But as it is left to the lessors option to take advantage of it or not, the election is not a condition precedent

anchor.surface_text: The position was not seriously disputed in the High Court or before us that the statutory provisions of section 111 g  as such cannot be made to govern the present lease which was executed in the year 1870.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease pre-1882 excluded by s2 TPA; 1929 amendment prospective per s63 Act XX 1929.

holdings.text: Section 63 of Act XX of 1929 restricts the operation of this amendment to transfers of property made after 1st April, 1930; amendment not retrospective.

anchor.surface_text: Section 63 of Act XX of 1929, restricts the operation of this amendment to transfers of property made after 1st April, 1930.

holdings.text: The particular provision introduced in sub-section g of section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act in 1929 is merely a procedural and technical rule introduced in the section by the legislature and is not based on any well established principles of equity.

anchor.surface_text: The main point for consideration - thus is whether the particular provision introduced in sub-section  g  of section 111 of the Transfer of Property Act in 1929 is but a statutory recognition of a principle of justice, equity and good conscience, or whether it is merely a procedural and technical rule introduced in the section by the legislature and is not based on any well established principles of equity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insistence on writing is formality; equity ignores forms; not in English law for non-payment; JEGC not altered by legislation.

holdings.text: The provision as to notice in writing as a preliminary to a suit for ejectment based on forfeiture of a lease is not based on any principle of justice, equity or good conscience and cannot govern leases made prior to the coming into force of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, or to leases executed prior to 1st April, 1930.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the provision as to notice in writing as a preliminary to a suit for ejectment based on forfeiture of a lease is not based on any principle of justice, equity or good conscience and cannot govern leases made prior to the coming into force of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, or to leases executed prior to 1st April, 1930.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural not equity; suit manifests election per English/common law precedents.

holdings.text: In England it is not necessary in case of non-payment of rent for a landlord to give notice before a forfeiture results; service of writ in ejectment sufficient.

anchor.surface_text: In England it is not necessary in case of non-payment of rent for a landlord to give notice before a forfeiture results. It cannot, therefore, be said that what has been enacted in sub-section g of section 111 is a matter which even today in English law is considered as a matter of justice, equity and good conscience.

holdings.reasoning_summary: English law (Foa, Law of Property Act s146(11)) no notice for rent non-payment; suit overt act.

holdings.text: The bringing by a landlord of a suit for ejectment is simply a mode of manifesting his election; forfeiture complete on breach, suit sufficient for pre-TPA leases.

holdings.text: The discretion given by section 114 is very wide; court to consider all circumstances and conduct of parties; no rigid rules.

anchor.surface_text: I desire in the first instance to point out that the discretion given by the section is very wide. The court is to consider all the circumstances and the conduct of the parties.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the provision as to notice in writing as a preliminary to a suit for ejectment based on forfeiture of a lease is not based on any principle of justice, equity or good conscience and cannot govern leases made prior to the coming into force of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882, or to leases executed prior to 1st April, 1930.
The High Court was therefore right in the view that it took of the matter and there are no valid reasons for taking a contrary view.

anchor.surface_text: In England it is not necessary in case of non-payment of rent for a landlord to give notice before a forfeiture results. It cannot, therefore, be said that what has been enacted in sub-section g of section 111 is a matter which even today in English law is considered as a matter of justice, equity and good conscience.
